title: Put Your Trust in the Tether: Photography Workflow
summary: Peter Hurley explains the benefits of shooting tethered for portrait photography. He emphasizes that tethering is not just for speed, but primarily a coaching tool that allows the photographer to show the subject their images in real-time, helping them adjust their expressions and angles for better results.

steps.action: Connect the camera to the computer using a high-visibility tether cable to prevent accidents.
Shoot directly to the computer to speed up workflow and avoid 'chimping' (looking at the back of the camera).
Use the tethered images to coach the subject, showing them what they are doing right or wrong to improve performance.
Photograph the subject while providing verbal direction, capturing various angles to learn their face.
Review the images on a large monitor with the subject, critiquing expressions and angles to identify the best looks.
Ensure technical proficiency (lighting and exposure) before tethering, as showing technically poor images can negatively impact the client's confidence.

key_takeaways: Tethering allows for immediate image transfer, eliminating the need for card readers and speeding up the review process.
The primary value of tethering is coaching; showing clients their photos helps them understand how to adjust their pose and expression.
Reviewing images together helps the photographer learn the subject's best angles and preferences.
Do not tether if your technical skills are lacking; showing bad lighting or exposure will hurt the session's energy.
Use high-visibility cables (like orange) to ensure safety on set.
